title: Festival Board v. Maya Patel — Generator Priority Dispute
summary: Generator rerouted from a festival rehearsal to keep insulin refrigerated during a storm.
story: During a storm-driven outage, logistics coordinator Maya Patel moved the esports lounge's backup generator to the community clinic after a nurse paged about insulin refrigeration. Festival organisers say stage lighting tests stalled for 90 minutes and accuse Patel of bypassing approval chains. Patel says the medical need outweighed practice delays and no equipment was damaged.

accuser.name: Festival Board
accuser.title: Campus Festival Organisers
accuser.summary: Claims Patel ignored the emergency escalation roster.

defendant.name: Maya Patel
defendant.title: Logistics Coordinator
defendant.summary: Rerouted generator for medical refrigeration and returned it within 90 minutes.

prosecutor.name: Silas Trent
prosecutor.title: Policy Prosecutor
prosecutor.summary: Wants a formal caution recorded for bypassing the chain of command.

defense.name: Advocate-Lambda
defense.title: Defense Counsel
defense.summary: Argues the emergency justified rapid improvisation.

charges: Count 2: Failure to log emergency hand-off

timeline.event: Storm knocks out power to the community wing.
Clinic nurse pages Patel requesting generator support.
Patel wheels generator to clinic; festival crew pauses lighting tests.
Generator returned and festival crew resumes.

evidence.label: Pager Log
evidence.detail: Timestamped request from clinic nurse at 19:19.

evidence.label: Generator Diagnostics
evidence.detail: Readouts show stable voltage during the hand-off.

aiSummary: Majority leans toward compassion but wants protocol clarified for next time.

comments.text: Rules exist for a reason. Coordinate first, improvise second.
Insulin would have spoiled. Patel likely prevented an ER visit.
We lost rehearsal momentum and volunteers. There has to be a call chain!

title: Dining Board v. Jordan Brooks — Allergen Exposure Incident
summary: Nut-free label moved during dinner rush, leading to a mild allergic reaction.
story: Community chef Jordan Brooks ran a chili buffet with a dedicated nut-free line. A volunteer shifted the signage while restocking bread, and a resident with a nut allergy took a scoop from the wrong pot. The resident used an inhaler but did not require hospitalization. Dining Board bots want mandatory retraining. Brooks apologised publicly and introduced color-coded ladles that night.
leadCharge: Negligent allergen management at community event

accuser.name: Dining Board
accuser.title: Allergy Safety Coalition
accuser.summary: Seeks formal retraining requirements for kitchen leads.

defendant.name: Jordan Brooks
defendant.title: Residence Chef
defendant.summary: Prepared separate pots but lost track of signage during rush.

prosecutor.name: Helena Cross
prosecutor.title: Health & Safety Prosecutor
prosecutor.summary: Pushes for suspension until training is complete.

defense.name: Counsel-Orion
defense.title: Defense Counsel
defense.summary: Points to immediate corrective action and minor harm.

judge.name: Judge Mercy
judge.title: Presiding Judge
judge.summary: Looks for restorative fixes and intent.

timeline.event: Separate nut-free pot prepped with dedicated ladle.
Volunteer shifts signage while restocking bread.
Color-coded ladles introduced; signage locked in place.

evidence.label: Volunteer Brief
evidence.detail: Email emphasising not to move allergen signage.

evidence.label: Clinic Report
evidence.detail: Resident treated on-site; no hospital transfer.

aiSummary: Public mood wants accountability plus permanent signage improvements.

comments.text: Labels are the first line of defence. This cannot be brushed aside.
Rush hour chaos is real. New color-coded ladles are a strong fix.
Great that the resident recovered, but protocols must be ironclad.

title: Safety Committee v. Lila Diaz — Badge Override Incident
summary: Expired clearance triggers a false alarm during a late-night lab visit.
story: Graduate assistant Lila Diaz used an expired badge override to enter the robotics lab after midnight and run a final thesis test. The security system triggered a gas suppression alarm. Safety Committee bots claim Diaz ignored the after-hours policy. Diaz says her advisor texted urgent permission and no damage occurred beyond a false alarm reset.

accuser.name: Safety Committee
accuser.title: Robotics Faculty Board
accuser.summary: Wants stricter controls on expired badge overrides.

defendant.name: Lila Diaz
defendant.title: Graduate Assistant
defendant.summary: Completed a thesis test and triggered the false alarm.

prosecutor.name: Ada Knox
prosecutor.title: Policy Prosecutor
prosecutor.summary: Argues the override endangers emergency responders.

defense.name: DefenseCounsel-AI
defense.title: Defense Advocate
defense.summary: Says Diaz secured advisor permission and prevented research loss.

judge.name: Judge Vega
judge.title: Presiding Judge
judge.summary: Evaluates data and harm before consequences.

timeline.event: Diaz enters lab using the expired override code.
Diaz contacts security to cancel the alarm.

evidence.label: Advisor Text
evidence.detail: Screenshot showing approval minutes before entry.

evidence.label: Security Log
evidence.detail: Alarm triggered and cancelled within 12 minutes.

aiSummary: Crowd is tense: equal parts policy outrage and sympathy for thesis pressure.

comments.text: Expired overrides are suspended for a reason. The alarm wasted responder time.
Advisor permission and quick cancellation show responsibility, not malice.
We rolled responders anyway. Someone has to pay for the false alarm.

title: Housing Council v. Priya Tal — Hackathon Noise Curfew
summary: Overnight coding sprint keeps an entire tower awake despite quiet hours.
story: Resident mentor Priya Tal approved an impromptu hackathon in the residence innovation lab. Neighbours reported nonstop clacking keyboards and cheering until 3 a.m., even after reminders about the midnight quiet rule. Tal says the event prevented students from commuting off-campus in a storm and she distributed earplugs. The housing council disagrees and filed for a misconduct review.
leadCharge: Quiet-hour violation and negligence in noise mitigation

accuser.name: Housing Council
accuser.title: Residence Oversight Board
accuser.summary: Filed the complaint after midnight logs showed repeated noise alerts.

defendant.name: Priya Tal
defendant.title: Resident Mentor
defendant.summary: Authorised the hackathon and claims earplugs and schedule notices were provided.

prosecutor.name: Silas Roe
prosecutor.title: Community Prosecutor
prosecutor.summary: Argues Tal ignored quiet-hour protocol and set a bad precedent.

defense.name: Counsel-Orion
defense.title: Defense Advocate
defense.summary: Points to the extreme weather keeping participants indoors.

judge.name: Judge Mercy
judge.title: Presiding Judge
judge.summary: Watches for intent and restorative outcomes.

charges: Count 1: Failure to enforce quiet-hour policy
Count 2: Negligent supervision of approved events

timeline.event: Hackathon setup begins in the innovation lab.
First quiet-hour alert is issued to Tal.
Second noise complaint recorded in guard log.
Housing council escalates to misconduct review.

evidence.label: Quiet Log
evidence.detail: Three entries in the quiet-hour incident report within one night.

evidence.label: Event Flyer
evidence.detail: Promotional flyer stating the event would wrap by midnight.

aiSummary: Dorm residents are furious; hackers insist the storm left no other option.

comments.text: Three separate warnings were ignored. A storm does not cancel policy.
We distributed earplugs and kept doors shut. The storm stranded us.
Earplugs do not fix cheering outside my door at 2 a.m.
